text:
What's the national speed
limit on motorways for cars
and motorcycles?

options.A: 70 mph
options.C: 50 mph
options.D: 60 mph

explanation: 70 mph. The national speed limit on motorways for cars and motorcycles is 70 mph in good conditions.

text:
Which vehicles should
use the left-hand lane on a
three-lane motorway?

options.A: Slow vehicles only
options.C: Large vehicles only
options.D: Any vehicle that isn't overtaking

explanation: Move to the left-hand lane. You should return to the left lane after overtaking when it's safe to do so.

text:
Your vehicle breaks down on a motorway and you 
need to call for help. Why might it be better to use an emergency roadside 
telephone rather than a 
mobile phone?

options.A: Mobile phones don't work on motorways
options.B: It allows easy location by the emergency services
options.C: Using a mobile phone will distract other drivers
options.D: It connects you to a local garage

explanation: Stay in your lane. On smart motorways, stay in your lane when the speed limit is shown above it.

text:
Your vehicle broke down on the hard shoulder of a 
motorway, but has now been repaired. How should you 
rejoin the main 
carriageway?

options.A: Move out onto the carriageway using your hazard warning lights
options.B: Move out onto the carriageway, then build up your speed
options.C: Gain speed on the hard shoulder before moving out onto the carriageway
options.D: Wait on the hard shoulder until someone flashes their headlights at you

explanation: Leave at the next exit. If you miss your exit, continue to the next one - never reverse or turn around.

text:
You're travelling along a
motorway. Where would you
find a crawler or climbing
lane?

options.A: Before a service area
options.C: Before a junction
options.D: Along the hard shoulder

explanation: Use the hard shoulder. In an emergency, stop on the hard shoulder as far left as possible.

text:
What do these motorway
signs mean?

options.A: They're countdown markers to the next exit
options.B: They're countdown markers to a bridge
options.C: They warn of a police control ahead
options.D: They're distance markers to the next telephone

explanation: Congestion ahead. An amber flashing light warns of a hazard ahead, typically congestion or an incident.

text:
Where are amber
reflective studs found on a
motorway?

options.A: Between the acceleration lane and the carriageway
options.C: Between the central reservation and the carriageway
options.D: Between the hard shoulder and the carriageway

explanation: At least two seconds. Use the two-second rule as a minimum safe following distance on motorways.

text:
What colour are the
reflective studs between the
lanes on a motorway?

options.A: Amber
options.C: White
options.D: Green

explanation: Switch on your hazard warning lights. Hazard lights warn following traffic that you're slowing or stopped.

text:
What colour are the
reflective studs between a
motorway and a slip road?

options.A: White
options.C: Red
options.D: Amber

explanation: Your vehicle is breaking down. The hard shoulder should only be used in emergencies.

text:
Your vehicle has broken down on a motorway. In 
which direction should you walk to find the nearest 
emergency telephone?

options.A: Facing oncoming traffic
options.C: In the direction of the nearest exit
options.D: In the direction shown on the marker posts

explanation: Cross to the emergency telephone. Use the emergency phone as it automatically identifies your location.

text:
What colour are the 
reflective studs between the hard shoulder and the left-hand lane of a motorway?

options.A: White
options.C: Red
options.D: Amber

explanation: Keep a safe distance. Maintain proper following distance even at motorway speeds.

text:
What should you do
when going through a
contraflow system on a
motorway?

options.A: Stay close to the vehicle ahead to reduce queues
options.B: Keep a good distance from the vehicle ahead
options.C: Use dipped headlights
options.D: Switch lanes to keep the traffic flowing

explanation: Not allowed to stop. Red X means the lane is closed - you must not drive in or stop in that lane.

text:
You're on a three-lane motorway. Which lane are you in if there are red 
reflective studs on your left and white ones to your 
right?

options.A: In the right-hand lane
options.C: On the hard shoulder
options.D: In the left-hand lane

explanation: Move back to the left. Return to the left lane after overtaking when it's safe.

text:
What should you do
when you're approaching
roadworks on a motorway?

options.A: Stay very close to the vehicle in front
options.C: Speed up to clear the area quickly
options.D: Obey the speed limit

explanation: Reflective studs on the road. Cats eyes help you see lane markings in the dark or poor weather.

text:
Which vehicles are
prohibited from using the
motorway?

options.A: Powered mobility scooters
options.C: Double-deck buses
options.D: Cars with automatic transmission

explanation: The left-hand lane. Always drive in the left lane unless overtaking.

text:
What should you do
while you're driving or riding
along a motorway?

options.A: Concentrate more than you would on other roads
options.B: Look much further ahead than you would on other roads
options.C: Travel much faster than you would on other roads
options.D: Maintain a shorter separation distance than you would on other roads

explanation: Reduce your speed. In fog or poor visibility, slow down appropriately.

text:
What should you do
immediately after joining a
motorway?

options.A: Try to overtake
options.C: Position your vehicle in the centre lane
options.D: Stay in the left-hand lane

explanation: Before joining the motorway. Adjust your speed on the slip road to match motorway traffic.

text:
When would you use the
right-hand lane on a three-
lane motorway?

options.A: When you're trying to save fuel
options.C: When you're overtaking
options.D: When you're travelling above the speed limit

explanation: Move back to the left lane. Don't stay in the overtaking lane longer than necessary.

text:
You're on a motorway.
The hard shoulder is not
being used as a running
lane. When should you use
the hard shoulder?

options.A: When you're joining the motorway
options.B: When you're stopping for a rest
options.C: When you're leaving the motorway
options.D: When you're stopping in an emergency

explanation: Stop on the hard shoulder. In emergencies, use the hard shoulder and call for help.

text:
You're in the right-hand
lane of a three-lane
motorway. What do these
overhead signs mean?

options.A: Leave the motorway at the next exit
options.B: Move to the left and reduce your speed to 50 mph
options.C: There are roadworks 50 metres (55 yards) ahead
options.D: Use the hard shoulder until you've passed the hazard

explanation: Stay in the left-hand lane. Keep left unless overtaking - this is the basic motorway rule.

text:
When are you allowed to
stop on a motorway?

options.A: When you wish to pick up hitchhikers
options.B: When you need to use a mobile telephone
options.C: When you need to walk and get fresh air
options.D: When you're signalled to do so by traffic signals

explanation: On your left. Vehicles can only pass you on the left on motorways and dual carriageways.

text: You're travelling in the left-hand lane of a three-lane motorway. How should you react to traffic joining from a slip road?

options.A: Switch on your hazard warning lights
options.B: Increase your speed to ensure they join behind you
options.C: Adjust your speed or change lane if you can do so safely
options.D: Maintain a steady speed

explanation: Check your mirrors. Always check mirrors before changing lanes or overtaking.

text:
How should you use the
lanes on a motorway?

options.A: Use the lane that has the least traffic
options.B: Keep to the left-hand lane unless you're overtaking
options.C: Overtake using the lane thatâ€™s clearest
options.D: Stay in one lane until you reach your exit

explanation: You're approaching a service area. This sign indicates a motorway service station ahead.

text:
You're travelling along a
motorway. When are you
allowed to overtake on the
left?

options.A: When the traffic in the right- hand lane is signalling right
options.B: When you warn drivers behind by signalling left
options.C: When in queues and traffic to your right is moving more slowly than you are
options.D: When you can see well ahead that the hard shoulder is clear

explanation: Leave at the next exit. Never reverse or turn back on a motorway.

text:
When would you use an
emergency area on a
motorway?

options.A: In cases of emergency or breakdown
options.B: If you think you'll be involved in a road rage incident
options.C: To stop and check where you are
options.D: To make a private phone call

explanation: Temporary maximum speed. This shows a variable speed limit on smart motorways.

text: Traffic officers operate on motorways and some primary routes in England and Wales. What are they authorised to do?

options.A: Stop and direct anyone on a motorway
options.C: Repair broken-down vehicles on the motorway
options.D: Stop and arrest drivers who break the law

explanation: Switch on hazard lights. Warn traffic behind you of the hazard ahead.

text:
You're on a motorway.
What does it mean when a
red cross is displayed above
the hard shoulder?

options.A: This lane can be used if you need a rest
options.B: You must not travel in this lane
options.C: Use this lane as a running lane
options.D: Pull up in this lane to answer your mobile phone

explanation: Use the hard shoulder. Stop as far left as safely possible in an emergency.

text: You're on a motorway. What does it mean when a mandatory speed limit is displayed above the hard shoulder?

options.A: You can pull up in this lane to answer a mobile phone
options.B: You shouldn't travel in this lane
options.C: The hard shoulder can be used as a running lane
options.D: You can park on the hard shoulder if you feel tired

explanation: Two seconds. Maintain at least a two-second gap in good conditions.

text:
How do motorways
reduce traffic bunching?

options.A: By using higher speed limits
options.C: By using advisory speed limits
options.D: By using variable speed limits

explanation: Amber flashing lights. These warn of hazards or congestion ahead on motorways.

text:
What helps to reduce
traffic bunching on a
motorway?

options.A: Contraflow systems
options.C: Lane closures
options.D: National speed limits

explanation: The left-hand lane. Stay left unless overtaking.

text:
When may you stop on a
motorway?

options.A: If you have to read a map
options.C: When you're tired and need a rest
options.D: If your mobile phone rings

explanation: Do not use this lane. A red X means the lane is closed - do not enter or use it.

text:
What's the national
speed limit for a car or
motorcycle on a motorway?

options.A: 50 mph
options.C: 70 mph
options.D: 60 mph

explanation: Before the broken line ends. Start signaling before the end of the slip road markings.

text:
You stop on the hard 
shoulder of a motorway and use the emergency 
telephone. Where's the best place to wait for help to 
arrive?

options.A: Next to the phone
options.C: Well away from the carriageway
options.D: With your vehicle

explanation: At the next exit. Continue to the next exit if you miss yours.

text:
You're on a motorway.
What must you do if there's
a red cross showing above
every lane?

options.A: Leave at the next exit
options.C: Slow down and watch for further signals
options.D: Stop and wait

explanation: It separates traffic flowing in opposite directions. The central reservation divides opposing traffic flows.

text:
You're on a motorway. What does it mean if a red cross is showing above the hard shoulder and 
mandatory speed limits 
above all other lanes?

options.A: The hard shoulder can be used as a normal running lane
options.B: The hard shoulder has a speed limit of 50 mph
options.C: The hard shoulder is for emergency or breakdown use only
options.D: The hard shoulder can be used as a rest area if you feel tired

explanation: You're joining a motorway. This is at the start of motorway slip roads.

text:
What does this
motorway sign mean?

options.A: Use any lane except the hard shoulder
options.B: Use all the lanes, including the hard shoulder
options.C: Use the three right-hand lanes only
options.D: Use the hard shoulder only

explanation: At a safe distance. Maintain proper spacing from the vehicle ahead.

text:
You have stopped in an
emergency area. What must
you do before you rejoin the
carriageway?

options.A: Move away with your hazard lights on
options.C: Give an arm signal as you are moving off
options.D: Switch on your vehicle's headlights

explanation: Match your speed to traffic in the left-hand lane. Adjust speed on the slip road to merge smoothly.

text:
How should you rejoin
the motorway after a
breakdown on the hard
shoulder?

options.A: Keep your hazard lights flashing until you have safely rejoined the carriageway
options.B: Build up speed on the hard shoulder before looking for a safe gap in the traffic
options.C: Move straight out into the left-hand lane as you are not allowed to drive on the hard shoulder
options.D: Wait until a vehicle in the left- hand lane signals to you that it's safe to rejoin

explanation: Leave at the next exit. Never reverse on motorways.

text:
What's the speed limit
for a car towing a trailer on a
motorway?

options.A: 70 mph
options.C: 50 mph
options.D: 40 mph

explanation: Use your mirrors more frequently. Increased mirror checks help track faster-moving traffic.

text:
When should you use
the left-hand lane of a
motorway?

options.A: When you're making a phone call
options.B: When the road ahead is clear
options.C: When your vehicle breaks down
options.D: When you're overtaking slower traffic in the other lanes

explanation: Wait for a gap in traffic. Don't force your way in - wait for a safe gap.

text:
You're driving on a 
motorway and have to slow down suddenly due to a 
hazard ahead. How can you warn drivers behind of the hazard?

options.A: Sound your horn
options.C: Switch on your hazard warning lights
options.D: Flash your headlights

explanation: Cross to the telephone on your side of the motorway. Always use the nearest phone for safety.

text:
Your car gets a puncture
while you're driving on the
motorway. What should you
do when you've stopped on
the hard shoulder?

options.A: Use an emergency telephone and call for help
options.C: Try to wave down another vehicle for help
options.D: Only change the wheel if you have a passenger to help you

explanation: Check for traffic coming up behind you. Always check mirrors before any maneuver.

text:
What should you do if
you're driving on a
motorway and you miss the
exit that you wanted to take?

options.A: Make a U-turn at the next gap in the central reservation
options.B: Carefully reverse in the left- hand lane
options.C: Carry on to the next exit
options.D: Carefully reverse along the hard shoulder

explanation: Move to the lane on your left. Return to the left after overtaking.

text:
Your vehicle has broken
down on a motorway. What
should you do if you aren't
able to get onto the hard
shoulder?

options.A: Switch on your hazard warning lights
options.B: Attempt to repair your vehicle quickly
options.C: Stop the traffic behind and ask for help
options.D: Stand behind your vehicle to warn others

explanation: Switch on your hazard warning lights. If you can't reach the hard shoulder, hazard lights warn other traffic of the danger.

text:
You're driving on a
motorway. What does it
mean if the car in front
shows its hazard warning
lights for a short time?

options.A: There's a police speed check ahead
options.B: The other car is going to change lanes
options.C: Traffic ahead is slowing or stopping suddenly
options.D: The driver wants you to overtake

explanation: Traffic ahead is slowing or stopping suddenly. Hazard lights briefly warn following traffic of sudden hazard ahead.

text:
What restrictions apply
to people who have a
provisional driving licence?

options.A: They can't drive with more than one passenger
options.C: They can't drive at night
options.D: They can't drive unaccompanied

explanation: They can't drive unaccompanied. Provisional license holders must be accompanied by a qualified driver.

text:
Your vehicle breaks 
down on a motorway and you manage to stop on the hard shoulder. What should you do if you use your 
mobile phone to call for 
help?

options.A: Wait in the car for the emergency services to arrive
options.B: Phone a friend and ask them to come and collect you
options.C: Check your location from the nearest marker posts beside the hard shoulder
options.D: Stand at the rear of the vehicle while making the call

explanation: Check your location from the nearest marker posts beside the hard shoulder. Marker posts help emergency services locate you precisely.

text:
You're towing a trailer
along a three-lane motorway.
When may you use the right-
hand lane?

options.A: When there's slow-moving traffic
options.B: When you can maintain a high speed
options.C: When large vehicles are in the left and centre lanes
options.D: When there are lane closures

explanation: When there are lane closures. Vehicles towing trailers can only use the right lane on 3-lane motorways during lane closures.

text:
What would you expect
to find at a contraflow
system on a motorway?

options.A: Wider lanes than normal
options.C: Lower speed limits
options.D: Road humps

explanation: Lower speed limits. Contraflow systems have reduced speed limits due to narrow lanes and opposing traffic.
